results.title: Structuring the learning environment (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Effective Behavioural Programming”.
Discusses four key points concerning the learning environment for severely and profoundly retarded students: the normalisation model; a ten point plan for increasing behaviour; the reasons why inappropriate behaviours occur; handling disruptive students

results.title: Structure within the image
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, CBS, KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.) and Coast Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Photographers Barbara Kasten and Garry Winogrand show how every photographer uses a unique structure within their work. Discusses framing, line, shape, tone and pattern and demonstrates ways to structurally improve photographs.

results.title: Structure of the atom
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
These programs explore the history and development of the model of the atom, from the hypothesis of early Greek philosophers to the wave-mechanical model of modern atomic physicists. Experiments by pioneer atomic scientists such as Bohr, Faraday, de Broglie and Rutherford are recreated through animation and their implications are discussed. The six 10 minute episodes are: 1. “The Earliest models” 2. “Smaller than smallest” 3. “The Rutherford Model” 4. “The Bohr Model” 5. “Spectra” 6.”The Wave-mechanic Model.”

results.title: Stronger since the war?
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Intertel, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Brett Porter
results.brief_description: Examines the status of women in Japan since the end of World War II, and their new social and economic conditions. Raises the question of whether the Japanese women are better off since their emancipation from the traditional way of life. Shows the changed life of women of the fishing villages and rice farms, and of women in the city; geishas, a Zen-Buddhist ‘Garden of Nothingness’, and the famous Japanese Tea Ceremony are also recorded. Awards: Winner of Silver Award, Documentary Category, Australian Film Awards, 1965)

results.title: Strong and safe
results.brief_description: A program focusing on IV users and HIV issues in the prison environment. Presents information on cleaning needles/syringes, obtaining new needles and syringes, and safe sexual practices by using humorous narrators - “Bleachman” and “Condomware Woman”! Messages are promoted in a positive, simple and practical manner and are geared to reinforcing safe injecting and sexual practices as they relate to IV drug use and the potential transmission of HIV within a prison oriented context.

results.title: Strokes
results.brief_description: Diagrams of the human body and the brain depict the causes of disease of the nerves which cause strokes. Explains how strokes may affect speech and memory and result in paralysis of the body or temporary weakness of the muscles. Rehabilitation training and natural replacement in damaged brain cell areas provide reassurance of possible recovery from strokes.

results.title: Stroke: the fight back
results.brief_description: Gives careful advice on how to care for stroke victims, such as encouraging daily muscle control pertaining to daily independence with the aid of a visiting nurse, physiotherapist, occupational therapist, speech therapy, medical social worker.
